title: What strange events were overshadowed by World War I or II? - Quora

response.answer_text: I do not understand what do you mean by “strange events”, but there is a strange event related to the Hitler’s attack on Soviet Union. It is contained in a legend narrated by Samarkand guides. In this ancient Asian city one of the main tourist attractions is Gur-i-Amir (a Persian for “The Tomb of the King”) Mausoleum - a mosque on the city’s central square; in its crypt was buried famous warrior Tamerlan, head of immense empire conquered by his sword. After the revolution of 1917 and an end of Bokhara khanate they turned the mosque in the museum, but entrance to crypt was restricted in respect to local superstitions spread even between members of Bolshevik party. Just the same, in Samarkand was a rather populous archeologist community, for excavations in the city were numerous and they usually gave many interesting results. For all these archaeologists one cherished dream was common; they ardently desired to open the great conqueror’s grave and explore it: was Tamerlan really buried there, how well preserved were remains; would it be possible to recreate his image by sculpture based on his scull and all that: one thousand and one question so very liked by scientists. But to open a grave a permission was needed, in that case, a permission from a highest places, for Samarkand bosses waited the permission from Uzbekistan's capital, Tashkent; Tashkent bosses needed a benevolent nod from Moscow and it did not came. Years went by but nothing changed. Then, suddenly, news circulated over the city by the word of the mouth: Tashkent got its plead back; in the document stood out Stalin’s instruction: “Open the grave not later than May 1941”. It was easier said than done: one ought to convoke a scientific commission, prepare tools and lights (for not to disturb the local feelings without a need, it was decided to make works during the night). At last works started in the night of 19 June; a strange event occurred: when scientists came to the Gur-i-Amir three old men waited for them; one of them had in hand an old book; the elders tried to explain something, but they spoke language scientists did not understood; they gently waived old men away, entered into the crypt and began to do their job. On the next day they were certain: it was Tamerlan’s entombment; they found a skeleton of a tall man lame in one leg; other details of the burial left no doubt: it was a king’s grave. Works were finished on the next night. Near midnight one of the scientists learned a rumour: some forgotten tradition, people said in Samarkand, held that somewhere in the Gur-i-Amir there was an ancient inscription that told: “The day the tomb of the Master of the World is disturbed, all oikoumene will shudder”. Scientists went out, their job completed, scull of Tamerlan was carefully packed and ready to travel to Moscow. It was an early morning of June, 22 1941. One hour later they knew that a war has just started.  Scientists near Tamerlan’s remains.  Tamerlan’s image restored by Prof. Mikhail Gerasimov.  Interior of the Tamerlan’s crypt. During World War 1, the “Spanish Flu Epidemic” was ravaging the entire world. Estimates go as high as 30 million killed. P.S. Spain didn’t cause the Spanish Flu. It got the name because only Spanish newspapers reported the flu. Most other nations were locked into WW1, and those governments only wanted to report good news, and hush up the bad news.
The miraculous Shackleton rescue was almost not reported at the time, ’cause the Great War had not broken out, when they left for Antarctica.
Probably the worst was the Spanish Flu epidemic of 1918 which killed more worldwide than were killed in the 4 years of war
